entry.title: Handling $filter,$search and $orderby in SAP CAP when consuming External REST APIs
entry.content:
Introduction

When building applications with the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), a very common real-world scenario is:

  • Your CAP service acts as a proxy
  • Data is fetched from an external REST API
  • The external API does not support OData

But your Fiori/UI5 frontend still sends OData queries like: 

$filter=country eq 'IN'&$search=Bangalore&$orderby=name desc

This blog explains how to handle OData query options like $filter, $search, and $orderby in SAP CAP Node.js when your service consumes a non-OData external REST API.

Here is a lightweight JavaScript utility (handleOData.js) that:

  • Interprets CAP‚Äôs query structure (req.query.SELECT)
  • Applies filtering logic directly on API responses
  • Adds full-text search capability
  • Supports dynamic sorting based on $orderby

With this approach, your Fiori/UI applications can continue using rich OData queries without any dependency on the external API.

This solution is ideal for building CAP-based proxy services on SAP BTP that integrate with legacy or third-party REST systems.

Problem Statement : 

Consider this scenario: Your frontend sends

GET /odata/v4/srv/DemandAreas?$filter=country eq 'IN'&$orderby=name asc

But your backend actually calls ,   

GET https://external.api/demandAreas

The external API:

  • Does not support $filter
  • Does not support $search
  • Does not support $orderby

Yet you still want your frontend to fully leverage OData features.

So how do we bridge this gap?

Architecture Overview:

Solution Overview: 

Utility file , handleOData.js exposes three main functions:

module.exports = { handleFilter, handleSearch, handleSort }

Each function handles a specific OData concept.

1. Handling $filter

CAP provides filters in a structured format (req.query.SELECT.where).

This utility interprets this structure and evaluates it against each result record.

Core logic idea:

function handleFilter(filters, item) {
  const stack = [];

  const applyComparison = (field, op, value) => {
    const fieldValue = item[field];

    switch (op) {
      case '=': return fieldValue == value;
      case '!=': return fieldValue != value;
      case '>': return fieldValue > value;
      case '>=': return fieldValue >= value;
      case '<': return fieldValue < value;
      case '<=': return fieldValue <= value;
      default: return false;
    }
  };

  // Logic continues to resolve AND / OR conditions}

This supports:

  • eq, ne, gt, ge, lt, le
  • Logical operations: AND, OR
  • Nested conditions

2. Handling $search

CAP exposes the search phrase via req.query.SELECT.search. The utility applies search across properties of each record.

Simplified logic:

function handleSearch(searchTerm, data) {
  return data.filter(item =>
    Object.values(item).some(val =>
      String(val).toLowerCase().includes(searchTerm.toLowerCase())
    )
  );
}

This allows our Fiori/UI app to use for example , $search=Bangalore

Even if the external API has no search support at all.

3. Handling $orderby

Ordering is handled using CAP‚Äôs orderBy structure.

Logic overview:

function handleSort(req, result) {
  const [orderClause] = req.query.SELECT.orderBy;
  const field = orderClause.ref[0];
  const dir = orderClause.sort === 'desc' ? -1 : 1;

  return [...result].sort((a, b) =>
    a[field] > b[field] ? 1 * dir : -1 * dir
  );
}

Supported:

  • $orderby=name asc
  • $orderby=createdAt desc

CAP Service Integration Example

Below is how you can plug this into your service implementation file:

const { handleFilter, handleSearch, handleSort } = require('./code/handleOData');
module.exports = (srv) => {

  srv.on('READ', 'DemandAreas', async (req) => {

    // 1. Call external REST APIlet data = await fetchExternalData();

    // 2. Apply $filterif (req.query.SELECT.where) {
      data = data.filter(item => handleFilter(req.query.SELECT.where, item));
    }

    // 3. Apply $searchif (req.query.SELECT.search) {
      data = handleSearch(req.query.SELECT.search, data);
    }

    // 4. Apply $orderbyif (req.query.SELECT.orderBy) {
      data = handleSort(req, data);
    }

    return data;
  });
};

Benefits of this Approach

  • Clean separation between CAP and external REST API
  • Full OData filtering support for Fiori/UI apps
  • No dependency on the external service supporting OData
  • Plug-and-play in any Node.js CAP project
  • Easy to extend with more operators

Conclusion:

This utility helps bridge the gap between OData-driven applications and non-OData REST services, while keeping our CAP service clean and the UI fully functional. If you‚Äôre building similar integrations, I hope this helps accelerate your work.

entry.title: Design Fiori Apps in Figma
entry.content:
Why SAP Fiori is the Future

With SAP Fiori, users not only get more modern applications but can also use apps via mobile devices like tablets or smartphones.

The SAP world is gradually shifting towards Fiori. Old technologies like SAP GUI or WDA are becoming things of the past, being replaced by the modern look and feel of Fiori interfaces.

Users benefit from a significantly better user experience. The individual apps are more consistent and uniform, which supports new users or occasional users in working smoothly. A fact that shouldn‚Äôt be underestimated is that 80% of all users in the Fiori environment use apps only occasionally (approx. 2 hours/week) and therefore don't know every app inside out.

But power users also benefit from Fiori apps and the new features they bring. SAP Fiori paves the way for AI - for instance, SAP‚Äôs new AI assistant ‚ÄúJoule‚Äù can be used directly within Fiori apps.

So, SAP Fiori opens up numerous potentials - for a modern look and feel, but also for utilizing the numerous standard applications that SAP provides in the Fiori Apps Library.

Designing Your Own Fiori Apps is the Right Way to Go!

Creating screen designs for SAP Fiori apps makes it possible to gather feedback from users at an early stage.

However, if the SAP standard doesn't fit your specific requirements, the best path is to design and develop your own Fiori apps. This way, you can create the best possible solution for your users and maintain full control over the associated processes and workflows.

Ideally, you can involve Key Users directly in the design of new Fiori apps. In the end, this ensures high user acceptance and happy users.

Designing Fiori Apps with Figma

Figma is a very well-known prototyping tool that UX designers typically use to create screendesigns and click dummies for new apps and websites. While the tool isn't specifically geared only towards SAP Fiori, it works excellently for designing Fiori apps when combined with the templates provided by SAP (the SAP Fiori Design Stencils).

It pays off to design Fiori apps with a tool like Figma before they go into development. This makes the planned solution tangible before investing the huge effort that comes with technical development. Future users can give their feedback based on screendesigns, allowing the Fiori app to be optimized directly. This guarantees an optimal solution without having to make many expensive adjustments to the productive app later on.

Designing Fiori apps in Figma specifically means that we create screendesigns. Such screendesigns show in true-to-life detail how the Fiori app will actually look in the end. The differences compared to the final development are minimal.

We can also easily arrange the Fiori screendesigns in Figma into click prototypes. This allows interactions and user flows (e.g., opening dialogs or navigating between screens) to be demonstrated clearly.

Note: Fiori apps can be designed in great detail in Figma. The final screendesigns are often indistinguishable from the implementation. Interactions like navigation between screens or dialogs can also be implemented easily in Figma.

Tutorial: How You Can Design Fiori Apps with Figma

1. Install Figma

Download page of the Figma desktop client.

Figma is the best tool for designing Fiori apps - precisely because SAP officially supports it by providing design templates. Figma can be used both in the browser and as an installed version.

Personally, I would recommend installing Figma, as the performance is often slightly better than in the browser. You can find the download on the official website:

In any case, you will need a free Figma account, which you should create now.

2. Install SAP Fiori Fonts

SAP page for downloading the required fonts "72" and "Business Icon Font".

To work seamlessly with the Fiori templates in Figma, you need to quickly install two fonts on your PC.

First is the SAP font "72", which you can download from SAP here:

And second is the "Business Icon" font, which you can download from SAP here:

Unzip both .zip files and then install the fonts.

3. Open Fiori Templates in Figma (SAP S/4HANA Web UI Kit)

Figma page of the SAP S/4HANA WEB UI Kit ‚Äì the official Fiori design templates from SAP for use in Figma.

To start creating designs for Fiori apps in Figma, it is necessary to open the official templates from SAP. These templates contain all the UI elements that exist in Fiori. From buttons, tables, or selection fields to complete pages and Fiori floorplans, such as the List Report or the Object Page, you will find everything you need here to design Fiori apps.

SAP provides different templates depending on whether you are creating a Fiori app for the Web, Android, or iOS. However, in 90% of cases, you will be designing your own Fiori apps for your SAP S/4HANA. Therefore, you can find the suitable templates here:

Note: SAP updates and expands this template regularly. Therefore, it is worth re-importing the Fiori templates every few months!

4. Overview of Fiori Templates in Figma

View of Figma with the opened page "List Report" from the "SAP S/4HANA Web UI Kit".

Once you have opened the Web UI Kit in Figma, you should see a long list of "Pages" in the left area of Figma. In these many pages, you will find the individual UI elements and templates of SAP Fiori that you can now use.

Take a few moments to get an overview. For example, on the "Buttons" page, we find all the numerous button types of Fiori. Under "Responsive Table," you will find something more complex: the tables you can use in your Fiori apps. And if you scroll down very far, you will find layout templates for all Fiori Elements floorplans under "List Report," for example.

And exactly this template is what we will grab in the next step!

Design Your First Fiori App with Fiori Elements Templates

From my experience as a Fiori UX Designer, 90% of all Fiori apps are implemented using Fiori Elements. Fiori Elements is a way to accelerate the development (and design) of custom Fiori apps by using ready-made templates ("floorplans"). If you've ever seen a Fiori app, you've most likely seen such a floorplan.

For our first Fiori app, we will also use such a floorplan as a foundation to speed up the design process while building a solid solution.

The Idea for Our Fictional Fiori App

Sketch of our planned Fiori app.

Our Fiori app should fulfill the following fictional use case:

  • On an overview: List all invoices my company has sent to customers and make them filterable.

  • On a detail view: Provide comprehensive information regarding a specific invoice.

From this use case, it follows that we need two screendesigns: the overview and the detail view. Ideally, we can use two classic Fiori Elements floorplans here: the List Report (for the overview) and the Object Page (for the detail view).

Designing a List Report in Figma

Copying the "List Report" into a new Figma file as a starting point for our Fiori app.

So let's start with the List Report. To do this, we open the previously opened Fiori templates in Figma again and go to the "List Report" page. There, we copy the layer "XL 1440px" on the left side and paste it into a new Figma file.

We can create a new Figma file by clicking on the small Figma icon in the top left -> File -> New Design File. In the new design file, you then paste the List Report template with Ctrl + V!

What you see now is an existing template for a List Report - the perfect starting point for our design. This template contains sample data that doesn't fit our fictional Fiori app - but we can change that quite easily.

Adjusting Texts

Adjusting texts in the "List Report". Here we are changing the column headers as an example ‚Äì in principle, all texts can be adjusted as desired!

If you press "T" and then click on an existing text with the mouse cursor, you can change it. With this, you can now adjust, for example, filter names, column headers, or texts in the tables and buttons.

Note: If changing a text is not possible, it might be that the required fonts are not installed. If changes are not possible despite installed fonts, I recommend using the Figma desktop client.

Deleting UI Elements

Deleting unneeded elements is done by selecting and pressing the "Delete" key. In this example, I am deleting some unneeded filters from the header.

If you no longer need elements, you can delete them. To do this, you have to click on the corresponding element and then press "Delete".

 

Note: You might have to click on an element multiple times to select it, as you are essentially clicking through the hierarchy in the design. This way, you can now delete filters, buttons, or table rows. If you make a mistake, you can undo it with Ctrl + Z.

Adapting UI Elements

Almost every Fiori UI element can be customized. To do this, you can select an element and see the associated settings options in the panel on the right side. In the example, I am changing the button style of the "Create" button.

Many UI elements can also be customized. For example, if you select the "Create" button, you will see properties on the right side that you can change. If you change the Type to "Primary", for instance, the button becomes a primary button and gets a blue background. You can adjust the look and feel of very many UI elements according to your wishes. Feel free to try out all options - you can't do anything wrong! üòâ

You can now also select the table ("Responsive Table") in the design and choose the value "Columns" for the "Structure" property. This ensures that you can adjust (delete or add) the individual columns of the table more easily.

For Our Example Fiori App

In our example, I am now adjusting the texts in the filters and the table according to the use case. I am removing unneeded filters and columns in the table. The end result is our List Report of the invoices!

Our final screen design for the overview page of our fictional Fiori app. Based on the floorplan, filters, columns, and buttons, for example, were adapted.

Designing an Object Page in Figma

Adapting the "Object Page" floorplan in Figma. Here I am removing some unneeded elements and adjusting the text of the title.

Now we want to create the detail page for a single invoice for our fictional Fiori app. To do this, we go back to the Fiori templates and switch to the "Object Page". Here we now see different variations of the Object Page for different screen sizes.

We simply click on the Object Page variant that is at the very top left, copy it again to the clipboard, and paste it into our Figma design where we have also placed the List Report.

Similar to the List Report, we can adapt the individual UI elements of the Object Page as we please - meaning we can: change texts, adapt or remove elements.

Adapting the Floorplan for Our Example Fiori App

Our detail page of an invoice, fully designed in Figma.

In our example, we primarily remove some UI elements that we don't need - for example, the graphic and the popover at the top left. We adjust texts and tables so that it fits our use case.

Prototyping: Linking the List Report and Object Page

After switching to "Prototype" mode, navigation from the overview page to the detail page can be implemented via drag-and-drop.

We have now designed two very simple views for our Fiori app. Now we can go a step further and insert interactions.

For this example, we will add navigation from the List Report page to the Object Page, as this is an integral part of our planned app.

To do this, we first have to switch to "Prototype" mode - we do this by clicking on the "Prototype" tab in the top right panel.

Then we select the arrow in the last column of the table from the List Report and drag-and-drop an arrow onto the Object Page.

Subsequently, we can also test the interaction in presentation mode. To do this, we select the List Report and click on the Play button at the top right. This opens a new tab.

If we have done everything correctly, we can now navigate to the Obect Page by clicking on the arrow in the List Report table!

Opening presentation mode by selecting the "Overview Page" and clicking the "Play" button at the top right.

Congratulations - You Have Designed Your First Fiori App!

In our example, we have now created two simple screendesigns based on existing templates ("floorplans") and linked them via prototyping.

If you have made it this far: Congratulations - you have successfully designed your first Fiori app! üôÇ

Deeper Adjustments of Floorplans and Designing Complex Fiori Apps

It is often necessary and useful to expand the designs even further. In principle, every aspect of such a screendesign can be adapted and expanded in Figma. New UI elements can be added, the layouting adjusted, or interactions such as opening dialogs and navigation up to concrete features can be realized in Figma.

The implementation possibilities have no limits here. If none of the Fiori Elements floorplans fit your use case, you can also design a Fiori Freestyle App in Figma.

However, all of this requires advanced skills and techniques in handling Figma for Fiori, which I deliberately do not want to include in this beginner's guide, as they often do not achieve the desired goal without direct guidance from an expert.

Conclusion & Key Takeaways

Designing Fiori apps doesn't have to be complicated. As we have seen, using Figma combined with the official SAP templates bridges the gap between complex technical requirements and a user-friendly interface.

Here are the key takeaways from this guide:

  • User Experience First: Moving to Fiori ensures a consistent, modern, and intuitive experience for your users.

  • Visualize Before You Build: Prototyping in Figma makes the solution tangible. It allows you to gather feedback from key users early, preventing expensive changes during the actual development phase.

  • Leverage Standards: You don't need to reinvent the wheel. Using Fiori Elements floorplans (like the List Report and Object Page) speeds up the design process significantly.

  • Official Resources: The SAP S/4HANA Web UI Kit in Figma provides you with everything you need to create professional and accurate designs.

Let's connect!

Do you need help or support using Figma for creating Fiori screendesigns? Or do you have specific questions about the workflow?

Feel free to send me a message or simply write a comment below this post. I am curious to hear about your experiences with designing Fiori apps!

A special thank you: Finally, I want to send a big thank you to the SAP Design Team for providing and regularly maintaining these Fiori templates for Figma. They are a massive help for the entire ecosystem and make our work as designers much easier.

Happy Designing!

entry.title: How to display Microsoft documents along with PDF and Images in SAP UI5 application
entry.content:
Overview:

Displaying Microsoft document type DOCX, PPT, XSLX etc. along with PDF and Image in SAP UI5/Fiori Application.

Business Requirement:

In one of my project, I have requirement where customer want to display all the attachments like docx, pdf, or pptx etc. inside fiori application. So, the user does not need to switch to different application on the system to view documents.

By default, Fiori provides preview capabilities for PDFs and images, but it does not support Microsoft file formats. But Since the customer needs to preview these file types directly inside the Fiori app, I explored alternatives and determined that the Apryse WebViewer SDK is capable of meeting this requirement

Note: This has additional licensing which customer procured in our case. There are few other libraries which you can utilize based on your requirement.

Step by Step Implementation:

  1. Create an MTA project and add a Fiori application to it.
  2. Now, we need to set up the webviewer sdk in the project. Open terminal from fiori application directory and run command npm i @pdftron/webviewer.
  3. Create a lib folder inside webapp and copy the core, ui, webviewer.min.js from node_modules/@pdftron/webviewer/public.

4. For our project, We created html div container which will display the document inside webviewer when user clicks on LoadDocument button.

5. In Controller, on onLoadDocumentPress, we will initialize and load webviewer like shown in below image

6. Open the terminal and run the command npm run start .

 

Note: License would be required to remove the watermark from the document.

Summary:

WebViewer supports viewing multiple document types, such as PDF, PPTX, and DOCX. In the example above, the document is rendered by converting a Base64-encoded string into a blob, but WebViewer also allows loading documents directly using a file path.

For more information, you can refer following link

Detailed code is available on github repo.

entry.title: Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
entry.content:
In our previous posts, we explored individual building blocks, their sophisticated capabilities, and how they come together in standard floorplans. We also learned how to extend these standard floorplans when needed. But what happens when your business requirements demand a layout that doesn't match any standard floorplan? The SAP Fiori development portal has you covered. In this post, we'll show you how to build a completely custom page layout while leveraging SAP Fiori elements building blocks to maintain enterprise-grade functionality.

When to Choose Custom Pages

Before we dive into creating custom pages, let's be clear about the decision path. If your UI requirements fit one of the existing standard floorplans (List Report, Object Page, Analytical List Page, Overview Page, or Worklist), you should absolutely use them. Standard floorplans offer:

  • Reduced development and maintenance costs
  • Automatic UI consistency across your application landscape
  • Built-in enterprise features that would take months to develop from scratch
  • Future-proof compatibility with SAP Fiori elements updates

However, when you need a special layout - like a wizard, shopping cart, or any non-standard UI pattern - you're not blocked. You can implement your custom layout while using as many SAP Fiori elements building blocks as possible to retain the benefits of the framework.

Exploring Custom Pages in the Portal

The SAP Fiori development portal's Custom Page  chapter provides comprehensive guidance for building custom layouts. Let's explore its key sections:

  • Overview - Shows a simple custom page demonstrating how building blocks integrate into custom layouts
  • Building Blocks Usage - Explains how to use SAP Fiori elements building blocks in existing UI5 freestyle applications, bridging the gap between traditional UI5 development and the SAP Fiori elements approach
  • Custom Root View - Demonstrates how to create and register custom root views when the standard options (FullScreen and Flexible Column Layout) don't meet your needs
  • Draft Handling - Shows how to leverage the Draft controller extension in your custom pages for seamless draft management

Fiori Development Portal: Custom page sample

These sections provide the foundation for understanding custom page development. Now let's put this knowledge into practice with a real-world example.

Building a Wizard: A Step-by-Step Journey

Let's create a wizard for travel request creation - a floorplan currently not available as a standard in SAP Fiori elements. We'll build this step by step, just as you would when developing your own custom page. The beauty of the portal is that you can experiment with code changes - auto-run is enabled by default, automatically refreshing the preview when you make simple changes. For more complex modifications, you can disable auto-run and manually click the "Run" button to update the sample when you're ready.

Step 1: Setting Up the Wizard Structure

Navigate to the Custom Pages Overview section in the portal. Click "Show Code" to open the code editor. We'll transform this simple page into a wizard.

First, let's add the wizard structure without any content in the steps. Replace the content of the CustomPageSample view with:

<mvc:View
	id="application-product"
	height="100%"
	controllerName="sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customPage.CustomPageSample"
	xmlns="sap.m"
	xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
	xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros"
>
	<macros:Page title="Create New Travel Request" class="sapUiContentPadding">
		<Wizard
			id="travelWizard"
			enableBranching="false"
			class="sapUiResponsivePadding--header sapUiResponsivePadding--content"
		>
			<WizardStep
				id="travelDataStep"
				title="Travel Information"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>

			<WizardStep
				id="approvalDataStep"
				title="Budget and Approval"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>

			<WizardStep
				id="bookingsStep"
				title="Bookings"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>

			<WizardStep
				id="reviewStep"
				title="Submit Travel Request"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>
		</Wizard>
	</macros:Page>
</mvc:View>

Now update the controller to support the wizard functionality. In the controller code editor, replace the CustomPageSample controller with:

import PageController from "sap/fe/core/PageController";
import MessageBox from "sap/m/MessageBox";
import type Context from "sap/ui/model/odata/v4/Context";

/**
 * Controller for the custom travel request wizard page.
 */
export default class CustomPageSampleController extends PageController {
	/**
	 * Creates a new travel request draft context and binds it to the view before rendering.
	 */
	public onBeforeRendering(): void {
		const view = this.getView();

		try {
			const model = view.getModel();

			// Create list binding and create a draft context
			const listBinding = model.bindList("/Travel");
			const wizardContext = listBinding.create({
				CurrencyCode_code: "EUR",
				BookingFee: 0,
				TotalPrice: 0,
				TravelStatus_code: "O"
			});

			// Bind the view to the created context
			view.setBindingContext(wizardContext);
			// Set the UI model property to make the forms and table editable
			view.getModel("ui").setProperty("/isEditable", true);
		} catch (error) {
			MessageBox.error("Failed to create travel request: " + (error as Error).message);
		}
	}

	/**
	 * Handler called when the submit button is pressed.
	 */
	public async onSubmitTravelRequest(): Promise<void> {
		// Navigate to the Object Page
		const routing = this.getExtensionAPI().getRouting();
		routing.navigate(this.getView().getBindingContext() as Context);
	}
}

You now have a working wizard structure with four steps! Before rendering the view, the controller's onBeforeRendering() method creates a new draft travel request and binds it to the view, so all our building blocks automatically work with this draft data. The onSubmitTravelRequest() method will be used later to finalize the wizard. For now, notice how the wizard steps are empty but navigable.

Preview wizard without step content

Step 2: Adding the First Form

Now let's add content to our first wizard step. This is where the portal becomes invaluable. You can either navigate to the Form Building Block in the same tab (the portal keeps your changes in memory as long as you don't refresh the browser), or better yet, open the portal in a second browser tab so you can reference the Form documentation while working on your wizard.

Open the Form page in the portal. You'll see it demonstrates the UI.FieldGroup#ApprovalData annotation. But we want to use a different field group for our first step. To see what's available, click "Show Code" next to the annotations example and look at the annotations.cds file in the code editor. You'll find several field groups, including TravelData, which is perfect for our first step.

Back in your wizard code, update the first WizardStep to include the form:

<WizardStep
	id="travelDataStep"
	title="Travel Information"
	validated="true"
>
	<MessageStrip
		text="Please provide the basic information about your travel request."
		type="Information"
		class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom"
	/>
	<macros:Form
		id="travelDataForm"
		metaPath="@UI.FieldGroup#TravelData"
	/>
</WizardStep>

Run the sample and navigate to the first step. You'll see the form with the travel data fields. 

Preview of first wizard step

Notice that the TravelID field appears as the first field. However, since travel IDs are calculated in the backend, it doesn't make sense to show this field here.

Let's remove it from the field group. Go back to the annotations.cds code editor and locate the TravelData field group. Remove the TravelID field:

FieldGroup #TravelData : {
	{ Value : BeginDate },
	{ Value : EndDate },
	{ Value : AgencyID },
	{ Value : CustomerID }
}

Click the "Run" button to refresh the preview with your changes - the TravelID field disappears! This demonstrates the power of annotation-driven UIs: simple metadata changes directly affect the user interface without touching the view code.

Preview without travel ID

Step 3: Adding the Budget & Approval Form

Now let's add the second form. Update the second WizardStep:

<WizardStep
	id="approvalDataStep"
	title="Budget and Approval"
	validated="true"
>
	<MessageStrip
		text="Provide budget information for approval."
		type="Information"
		class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom"
	/>
	<macros:Form
		id="approvalDataForm"
		metaPath="@UI.FieldGroup#ApprovalData"
	/>
</WizardStep>

This step uses the ApprovalData field group, which contains financial information like booking fee and total price. The same building block, configured differently through the metaPath property, delivers completely different content.

Preview second wizard step

Step 4: Adding the Bookings Table

The third step needs a table for managing flight bookings. Navigate to the Table Building Blocks in the portal. Study how the table building block works, paying special attention to the metaPath property.

For our wizard, we want to display bookings that are associated with the travel request. Since our view is bound to a Travel context, we need to set the metaPath to the bookings navigation. Update the third WizardStep:
 

<WizardStep
	id="bookingsStep"
	title="Bookings"
	validated="true"
>
	<VBox>
		<MessageStrip
			text="Add flight bookings for your travel. You can add multiple bookings."
			type="Information"
			class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom"
		/>

		<macros:Table
			id="bookingsTable"
			metaPath="/Travel/to_Booking/@UI.LineItem"
			personalization="Sort,Column"
			header="Flight Bookings"
			creationMode="NewPage"
		/>
	</VBox>
</WizardStep>

Run the sample and navigate to the Bookings step. Click the "Create" button in the table toolbar. You can now create bookings! The table building block automatically provides creation, editing, and deletion capabilities based on the entity's capabilities defined in the service metadata. This is enterprise-grade functionality delivered through a single building block with minimal configuration.

Preview third wizard step

Step 5: Submitting the Travel Request

The final step allows users to review and submit their travel request. Update the fourth WizardStep:

<WizardStep
	id="reviewStep"
	title="Submit Travel Request"
	validated="true"
>
	<VBox class="sapUiContentPadding">
		<Text
			text="You have successfully completed all steps. Your travel request is ready to be submitted."
			class="sapUiMediumMarginBottom"
		/>

		<HBox justifyContent="End" class="sapUiMediumMarginTop">
			<Button
				text="Submit"
				type="Emphasized"
				press="onSubmitTravelRequest"
				icon="sap-icon://paper-plane"
			/>
		</HBox>
	</VBox>
</WizardStep>

 Notice that we're not saving the draft directly using the EditFlow controller extension. Instead, when users click "Submit", the onSubmitTravelRequest method in our controller uses the routing API to navigate to the travel request's Object Page:

public async onSubmitTravelRequest(): Promise<void> {
	// Navigate to the Object Page
	const routing = this.getExtensionAPI().getRouting();
	routing.navigate(this.getView().getBindingContext() as Context);
}

With this approach, users can review their complete travel request in the standard Object Page layout, make any final changes, and then save it using the familiar Object Page header actions. This demonstrates an important principle: you can mix custom pages with standard floorplans in the same application, using each where it fits best.

The Power of Building Blocks in Custom Pages

What we've built demonstrates the core value proposition of SAP Fiori elements building blocks in custom pages:

  • Rapid Development - We created a sophisticated multi-step wizard with forms, tables, and draft handling in minutes, not days
  • Enterprise Features - Each building block brings personalization, validation, error handling, and accessibility automatically
  • Annotation-Driven - Business logic changes (like removing the TravelID field) require only metadata updates, not code changes
  • Consistency - The forms and table in our wizard look and behave exactly like those in standard floorplans, ensuring UI consistency
  • Flexibility - We combined building blocks with standard UI5 controls (Wizard, MessageStrip, Button) to create a layout not available in standard floorplans

Key Takeaways

When building custom pages with SAP Fiori elements:

  • Choose Wisely - Use standard floorplans whenever possible. Resort to custom pages only when your layout requirements genuinely don't fit standard patterns
  • Maximize Building Block Usage - The more you use SAP Fiori elements building blocks in your custom pages, the more enterprise features you get for free
  • Leverage the Portal - Use the SAP Fiori development portal to understand building block capabilities, experiment with configurations, and see immediate results
  • Mix and Match - Combine custom pages with standard floorplans in the same application, using each where appropriate
  • Stay Annotation-Driven - Even in custom pages, let annotations drive as much behavior as possible to minimize code and maximize maintainability

What's Next

In our final post, "Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)," we'll explore options to advance portal features and how to best include all project team members for maximizing productivity.

 

To get the full overview about the SAP Fiori development portal, check out the following blog posts of the mini-series:
  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6)
  • Get familiar with SAP Fiori development portal and the power of the building blocks (2 of 6)
  • Explore the potential of SAP Fiori development portal using complex building blocks (3 of 6)
  • Use SAP Fiori development portal to understand extension options for standard floorplans (4 of 6)
  • Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
  • Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)

entry.title: A Practical Real-Time CTI Widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
Over the last weeks, I've been working on a CTI widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2 and wanted to share the practical setup I used to get it running in a production-ready way. The goal was simple: receive real-time call events from a telephony system and push them into Sales Cloud without relying on any custom back-end inside the CRM.

A small CAP backend, a WebSocket channel, and a UI5 widget were enough to make this work end-to-end.

Overall Architecture

The widget runs in an iframe inside SAP Sales Cloud. A CAP service on BTP receives call events from the telephony provider and forwards them to the widget via WebSocket. The widget then sends a formatted XML payload back to Sales Cloud using postMessage.

 

CAP Service with WebSocket Support

The backend uses CAP v9 with Websocket enabled so the widget can react immediately to incoming call events.

@protocol: ['websocket', 'odata']
service WidgetService {
  action notifyEvent(
      date : String,
      caller : String,
      isAnonymous : String,
      callee : String,
      event : String,
      direction : String,
      LID : String
  ) returns String;

  event eventNotification : CTIEvent;
}

Event Handler is handling the incoming event and emits it to connected WebSocket clients. 

this.on("notifyEvent", async (req) => {
  const eventData = req.data;
  await this.emit('eventNotification', eventData);
  return 'OK';
});

WebSocket channel is enabled using the @cap-js-community/websocket plugin. Also we configured the xs-app.json file.

{
"websockets": {
    "enabled": true
  }
}

Mapping the CTI Event for Sales Cloud

Sales Cloud expects a specific XML payload.
The widget maps incoming CTI data into that format.

function mapToSapPayload(cti) {
  const ev = (cti.event ?? "").toUpperCase();
  const dir = (cti.direction ?? "").toUpperCase();

  let eventType = dir === "OUTBOUND" ? "OUTBOUND" : "INBOUND";
  let action = "NOTIFY";

  switch (ev) {
    case "CONNECTED":
    case "ANSWERED":
      action = "ACCEPT";
      break;
    case "ENDED":
      action = "END";
      eventType = "UPDATEACTIVITY";
      break;
  }

  return {
    Type: "CALL",
    EventType: eventType,
    Action: action,
    ANI: cti.caller || "",
    ExternalReferenceID: cti.LID
  };
}

Sending the Event to Sales Cloud (postMessage)

The widget sends the XML using a postMessage call. After that, SAP Sales Cloud receives it and Desktop Agent creating a new live Interaction. See more in @lloyd_goveia 's post called 'How Can You Simplify SAP Service Cloud CTI Integration Testing? Try This Dynamic POC Widget!'.

const xml = jsonToXml(sapPayload);
window.parent.postMessage(xml, "*");

Here is an example payload. See more in SAP Help Portal.

<payload>
  <Type>CALL</Type>
  <EventType>INBOUND</EventType>
  <Action>NOTIFY</Action>
  <ANI>+123456789</ANI>
  <ExternalReferenceID>CALL123</ExternalReferenceID>
</payload>

SAP Sales Cloud reads sent mesagge only if CTI is enabled for the tenant, follow the SAP Help Portal doc for more detail. 

Security Notes

The SAP Sales Cloud domain was added to the App Router allowlist (whitelist) to ensure that SAP Cloud is able to load the widget in an iframe. we need to configure the whitelistService propery in xs-app.json.

{
  "whitelistService": {
    "endpoint": "/whitelist/service"
  },
  "responseHeaders": [
    {
      "name": "Content-Security-Policy",
      "value": "frame-ancestors https://*.crm.cloud.sap"
    }
  ],
  "routes": [
    {
      "source": "^/whitelist/service$",
      "localDir": ".",
      "authenticationType": "none",
      "cacheControl": "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate"
    }
}

For more information, please visit @sap/approuter in npmjs.com.

Configure SAP Sales Cloud CTI Configuration

There are a few CTI settings that need to be enable first to make the widget show up inside SAP Sales Cloud V2. 

  • Enable CTI Integration --> See SAP Help Portal
  • Register the Widget --> See SAP Help Portal 

Source Code 

The base code is available on Github as a public repo.

Repository Name: gizemsoylutr/sales-cloud-cti-widget

entry.title: Understanding Regex in JavaScript - A Beginner-Friendly Guide
entry.content:
Quick Introduction:

When working with JavaScript, we will often find ourselves needing to search, validate or modify text. That‚Äôs where Regex comes in.

In this blog, we will break down what regex is, why it‚Äôs useful, and how to start using it with simple examples.

 

What is Regex?

Regex is a powerful & smart search tool that lets you find patterns in text almost like giving your code a mini detective to look for clues inside a string.

Regex (short for Regular Expression) is a special pattern used to search, match and replace text.

In other words, regex is a pattern-matching language used in many programming languages, including JavaScript to:

  • Search for text
  • Match specific patterns
  • Replace parts of a string

For example, we might need to check if a sentence contains a word, extract all numbers from a paragraph or validate an email address. Regex makes these tasks fast, efficient and reliable.

 

Why do use Regex in JavaScript?

Because normal search is limited. With regex, we can do so much. Regex lets you write dynamic, flexible patterns to handle more advanced text operations. Here‚Äôs what you can do with it:

  1. Validate patterns

    Modify text based on matching patterns.
    Example: Remove extra spaces or replace characters.

  2. Extraction Text

    Check if a string follows a specific format.
    Example: Is this a valid email address?

  3. Replace text

    Pull out numbers, words or custom text patterns.
    Example: Find all digits in a message.

 

Simple and Practical Examples

Let‚Äôs look at how we can use regex in JavaScript with just a few lines of code.

  • Check if a word exists
const sText = "I love JavaScript";

const bResult = /JavaScript/.test(text);

console.log(bResult); // true
  • Find all numbers in a string
const sText = "My score is 95 out of 100.";

const sNumbers = sText.match(/\d+/g);

console.log(sNumbers); // ["95", "100"]
  • Replace spaces with dashes
const sResult = "hello world js".replace(/\s/g, "-");

console.log(sResult); // "hello-world-js"

 

How regex patterns are structured & how it works

Regex patterns in JavaScript are written between forward slashes:

/pattern/

Here are some common symbols:

Symbol

Meaning

\d

digit (0‚Äì9)

\s

whitespace (space, tab, etc.)

\w

word character (letters, numbers, _)

+

one or more

*

zero or more

Based on our requirement, we can combine these symbols to create almost any pattern we need.

In simple words, Regex is a smart text-searching tool in JavaScript. It helps us work with text faster, cleaner, and more efficiently, especially when dealing with patterns. Whether you're searching, matching or validating text, regex makes the process powerful, flexible and easy.

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! I hope this helps you. If you found this helpful, please feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments. Let's keep learning and growing together!

Stay tuned for more in-depth knowledge on regex tool in future blogs. Happy coding!

Dear experts, I‚Äôm new to blogging, please feel free to correct me if any information is inaccurate.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì In-depth analysis of SAP Fiori content changes during system upgrade
entry.content:
TL;DR SAP Fiori content can change during upgrades. Not only the app lifecycle influences the app availability and usage, attributes of SAP Fiori apps (e.g. tile title, application resource, ‚Ä¶) can change as well and this will have an impact on your end users UX, if you don‚Äôt pay attention and address it via change procedures.

If you upgrade your SAP S/4HANA system version, there will be changes in the availability of SAP Fiori apps. Some will be deprecated, available with successor, obsolete/unavailable, or are not affected by any change. This will be highlighted by the SAP Fiori Upgrade Impact Analysis.   

The necessary prerequisites related to the SAP Fiori Upgrade Impact Analysis can be found either in the SAP Blog SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Upgrade Impact Analysis or on the SAP Help page SAP Fiori Upgrade Impact Analysis.
Additionally, the following SAP Blog offers you insights in the app lifecycle of SAP Fiori apps: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Upgrade Faster ‚Äì Managing app lifecycle impacts on users.

After reading through these documentations, you should be aware of the SAP Fiori upgrade process and what the app lifecycle statuses (deprecated, obsolete, available with successor, ‚Ä¶) are referring to.

Let‚Äôs get into the details of what changes can occur in SAP Fiori content during a system upgrade.

Type of changes to SAP Fiori content

  1. Changes in the features/functionalities of SAP Fiori apps
    Please check the What's New Viewer - ABAP Platform to get updates on the functional changes happening in the SAP Fiori apps.
  2. Changes to feature/functionalities in the SAP Fiori launchpad
    Please check the What's New Viewer - ABAP Platform to get updates on the new features delivered with each SAP Fiori FES version.
  3. Changes to SAP Fiori Launchpad App Descriptor Items (LADI)
    This is the focus topic of this SAP Blog, as it is scope of the ‚ÄúAdvanced Upgrade Impact Analysis‚Äù.

SAP Fiori App changes on LADI

There is a multitude of changes that can happen during an SAP Fiori Upgrade.

In this blog I decided to use an upgrade scenario from SAP S/4HANA 2022 FPS01 to SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 as a case example. During my evaluation I used the SAP standard roles to illustrate the changes that can happen.
We are going to use four types of change priorities to describe the change impact of relevant LADI attributes that impacts end users.


To get a list of all LADI relevant attributes we are using the transaction /UI2/FLPCA for exporting‚Ä¶ With this export we are able to get a quick overview of the SAP Fiori content in customer or SAP standard roles.

In SAP S/4HANA 2023 the report has a total of 63 columns that can be exported.
Out of these 63 a total of 22 can contain end user relevant changes.
If you see that a column appears multiple times, that column can contain different type of issues.

For instance,  the column Title/Subtitle/Information can contain issues related to:

  • Change of information displayed on tile
    This is rated as Medium
  • {Reference Lost} or {Reference Lost to Backend Catalog}
    This is rated as High

Below, you see an overview of the different end user relevant columns prioritized by possible impact during system upgrade.

*rating of these attributes can vary based on your end users change resilience/innovation acceptance threshold

Now, let‚Äôs dive into some specific examples to make this topic more tangible.

One more comment before showing some examples‚Ä¶
These apps are chosen without any additional intention behind displaying them.
The examples are chosen at random

1. Title/Subtitle/Information changed

As an example, we are going to take the roles SAP_BR_CONTRACT_MANAGER_CCM and SAP_BR_CONTR_MGR_ROYALTIES.
The structure of this field is as follows: Tile Title ‚Äì Tile Subtitle / Tile Information

In the picture below you can see that we have a small change, information from the Tile Title has been written into the Tile Subtitle.

How is this change reflected in the SAP Fiori launchpad?

2. Application resource changed

The following example from role SAP_BR_BUDGET_RESPONSIBLE shows that in the business catalog SAP_PSM_BC_BDGTRESP_MD the application resource for the tile ‚ÄúDisplay Grant‚Äù changed.

As depicted in the screenshot below, taken from SE93, the programs behind these transactions are different. This can have a functional impact.
Your functional colleagues need to review, if the application is still suited to perform all the necessary process steps designated to that application.

3. Semantic Object and Action changed

The combination of semantic object and action is used for the intent-based navigation.

As this is relevant for the navigation network/flow of applications connected with each other, a potential change can have an impact on the process flow of end users working with these applications.

If such a change is detected, the applications in its process flow need to be verified again.

With these examples shown, I don‚Äôt want to discourage you in performing upgrades.
Rather I want to highlight the importance of proper testing during upgrades.
The SAP Fiori content can and will change during a system upgrade.
Preparing for this change via change management is crucial to ease your end users into the new SAP S/4HANA version.

Changes in Z-roles created with SAP standard content

You followed the SAP best-practices and copied the SAP standard business catalogs to your own Z-version of these content entities?
Independent of whether you are using SAP created business catalogs or business catalogs created by you, they are all referencing to the content from the technical catalogs.
If a LADI object changes in the original persistence (technical catalog), the LADI object will be changed in the reference (business catalog), as well.
Therefore, even if you use Z-catalogs and reference content from SAP technical catalogs, your content will be affected from the changes coming with the SAP Fiori upgrade as well.

This is a double-edged sword:

  1. You are getting changes from SAP standard content by referencing from SAP technical catalogs and therefore stay close to SAP Standard.
  2. Changes to content in SAP technical catalogs are reflected in your referenced content added to your business catalogs and hence will be in your system after the upgrade.

Since this is the best practice for multiple reasons, your content is going to change with an upgrade of the system version.

Now to the big question: can we support you in the process of SAP Fiori upgrade by highlighting these changes directly in your customer specific roles?

Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis

The Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis is a SAP delivered service providing you with the results via a service report to give you clarity on SAP Fiori changes during an upgrade.
We are combining the learnings from analysing the content in one source of truth and highlight the changes with recommendations fitting to each of these different changes.

What is required to perform the Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis?

We need two different exports to perform the in-depth analysis.

  1. SAP Fiori content of customer source system, this is an export of all customer relevant role data before the upgrade.
  2. SAP Fiori content of customer target system, this is an export of all customer relevant role data after the upgrade.

 

It is recommended to export the role data from the development system before performing an upgrade to a higher SAP S/4HANA version.
Ideally, no further changes to the role content are taken after the export has been performed.

The analysis of the content changes is conducted on entry level.
An entry is equal to an application, in a role in a catalog.

E.g. ME23N is in business catalog Z_BC_MM_PUR_DIS assigned to role Z_BR_MM_PUR_DIS.
Each entry in your custom roles can be sorted into the following categories:

1. Unchanged

This means that all end user relevant attributes of the SAP Fiori content remain unchanged and the application lifecycle status is ‚Äúavailable‚Äù or ‚Äúunknown‚Äù.

2. Changed

This means that at least one end user relevant attribute of the SAP Fiori content changes and/or the application lifecycle status is ‚Äúobsolete‚Äù, ‚Äúdeprecated‚Äù, ‚Äúavailable with successor‚Äù.

Changes on LADI level are highlighted, e.g. change on Title/Subtitle/Information.

3. Added

This means that the entry is part of the SAP Fiori content after the upgrade, e.g. got added by your administrators before taking the export or can‚Äôt be matched correctly due to reference lost issues.

4. Removed

This means that the entry is part of the SAP Fiori content before the upgrade, but not after.
E.g. got deleted by your administrators before taking the export or can‚Äôt be matched correctly due to reference lost issues

 How can you order this service?

If you already are a Premium Engagement customer, contact your SAP Technical Quality Manager (TQM) to discuss how Premium Engagement Service can help you with a custom-tailored and efficient service portfolio to make your project a success!
With the Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis, we are happy to support you with tailored insights and guidance for your system upgrade!
Discover further insights into SAP Premium Engagement and explore how an international team of specialists can assist you in maximizing the value of your SAP solutions.

If you are not a Premium Engagement customer and still want to take advantage of the Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis, please align with your SAP Service Partner or SAP Account Responsible.

entry.title: Harmonizing UI5 URLs: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN
entry.content:
What Do We Do?

To further enhance consistency and ease of access, we are now making the convenient URLs the new default for all Demo Kit  resources. The following table shows the previous URLs and their short an convenient URLs:

Previous URLs

Short and Convenient URLs

openui5nightly.hana.ondemand.com

sdk.openui5.org/nightly

openui5.hana.ondemand.com

sdk.openui5.org

sapui5.hana.ondemand.com

ui5.sap.com

This follows our initial announcement ‚ÄúShort and Powerful: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN‚Äù.

Why We‚Äôre Doing This

One URL for OpenUI5 and one for SAPUI5 improves search engine indexing and discoverability which will lead to better search results. It will simplify the access to our documentation and tools for developers and establishes consistent and future-proof domains which are independent from the platform they are served from.

What Will Happen?

To make the transition as easy as possible, we will gradually redirect users to the new URLs. Here‚Äôs what you can expect:

  • Demo Kit Resources (HTML pages) will be automatically redirected to the new URLs starting on:
    • OpenUI5: December 8th
    • SAPUI5: January 7th
  • Runtime Resources (everything else) will be redirected to the new URLs starting on:
    • OpenUI5: January 7th
    • SAPUI5: ~UI5con Germany 2026

These steps are designed to give everyone plenty of time to adjust to the new URLs and ensure a seamless experience.

What You Should Do Now

Make use of the short and convenient URLs now by...

  • ...updating your bookmarks to the Demo Kit to use the new domains
  • ...adopting your applications to bootstrap OpenUI5 or SAPUI5 from the new domains
  • ...sharing this update with your teams and communities to help us spreading this information (Hint: still the old netweaver.ondemand.com URLs are in use!!)

Although we redirect the existing URLs they are going to continue to work. Once the old URLs will be sunset, we‚Äôll inform you early enough upfront.

Note: To bootstrap SAPUI5 in non-cloud scenarios please use the Standard Variant for Bootstrapping. See details on the difference in Docu: Bootstrapping from Content Delivery Network and in note 2943781.

Another note on Tracking Prevention when using these URLs: Please mind the respective information in "Browser and Platform Support" for SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 and note 3216225 on how to handle it.

entry.title: Consuming your own (or external) Web Components in UI5 Applications
entry.content:
Consuming your own (or external) Web Components in UI5 Applications

This post summarizes my learnings on how to consume arbitrary web components natively in UI5 applications. This is a powerful alternative to UI5 custom controls, since web components are framework-agnostic and can be reused in other contexts as well.

A lot of people perceive UI5 as a control library only, or at least a frontend framework that is very closely tied to its control library, but it's actually much more than that. It's a very powerful and flexible framework that can be extended and used in many different ways.

During the Developer Keynote at SAP TechEd on Tour Bangalore 2025 (no online recording unfortunately), I demoed the flexibility and openness of UI5 by showing two approaches for extending UI5 application with custom elements:

The first approach has been around for quite a while and is well known: developing UI5 custom controls. With this approach, you essentially create new UI5 controls by extending existing UI5 controls. This approach has the advantage of being fully integrated into the UI5 framework, but it also means it is tightly coupled to UI5. You cannot reuse UI5 custom controls for applications that are not based on UI5. However, since third-party packages (e.g. from npm) can be consumend inside UI5 applications as well (see ui5-tooling-modules), this approach is by no means limited. Check out this repository for detailed instructions on how to build a UI5 custom control that renders a 3D model of a supermarket to guide customers to a product's location: ui5-advanced-exercises-codejam

The second approach is very new to UI5: building your own web components and consuming them natively in UI5 applications. This approach is framework-agnostic, as the technologies that make up web components are open web standards. This means you can (re)use the same web components in any web application, regardless of the framework. Think of whole design systems that could be built using this approach, and then be reused in UI5/React/Angular/Vue applications alike! This blog post focuses on this second approach.

To demonstrate this capability, we first need a web component. For the sake of simplicity, I created a very basic web component that displays a button, and when clicked, shows an alert. The code for the web component looks like this:

class CustomAlertButton extends HTMLElement {

    static get observedAttributes() {
        return [
            "text",
            "message"
        ]
    }

    attributeChangedCallback(name, oldValue, newValue) {
        this.render()
    }

    constructor() {
        super()

        /**
         * Sets the button's text.
         * @default "Show Alert"
         * @public
         */
        this.text = "Show Alert"

        /**
         * Sets the alert message.
         * @default ""
         * @public
         */
        this.message = ""

        this.attachShadow({ mode: "open" })
        this.render()
    }

    render() {
        const text = this.getAttribute("text") || this.text
        const message = this.getAttribute("message") || this.message
        let button
        if (!this.shadowRoot.querySelector("button")) {
            button = document.createElement("button")
            this.shadowRoot.appendChild(button)
        } else {
            button = this.shadowRoot.querySelector("button")
            button.textContent = text
            if (message) {
                button.addEventListener("click", async () => {
                    alert(message)
                })
            }
        }
    }
}

customElements.define("custom-alert-button", CustomAlertButton)

There are two things important to note regarding the implementation above:

  1. For some reason I don't fully understand yet, the render method of the web component will get executed three times when the component is first rendered in a UI5 application. Therefore, the method includes some conditional logic to avoid adding multiple buttons or event handlers to the shadow DOM.
  2. The static getter observedAttributes as well as the JSDoc comments in the constructor method are mandatory in order for UI5 to be able to recognize the web component correctly and integrate it into its data binding and property system. Furthermore, we have to generate a custom-elements.js manifest file that describes the web component's API. This can be done using the @custom-elements-manifest/analyzer package. After installing it as a dev dependency, you can run the following command to generate the manifest file:
custom-elements-manifest analyze

This will create a custom-elements.json file in the root of your project. The file tree of your custom web component package should now look like this:

custom-webc-package/
|-- custom-elements.js
|-- CustomAlertButton.js
|-- package.json

With the custom web component package ready, we can now consume it in a UI5 application. To do so, we first need to install it as a dependency. In the package.json of the UI5 application, add it as a dependency and run npm install afterwards:

...
{
  "dependencies": {
    "custom-webc-package": "file:<path-to-your-custom-webc-package>"
  }
}
...

At this point you might be thinking "wait, I can just declare any package as a dependency and use it in UI5?!" - and the answer is yes, with the help of the ui5-tooling-modules package, which allows you to consume arbitrary npm packages in UI5 applications. So make sure you have it set up in your UI5 application.

Now that the custom web component package is installed, its consumption is very straightforward. Simply declare a namespace in an XML view that points to the package, and use the web component like any other UI5 control:

<mvc:View
    ...
    xmlns:webc="custom-webc-package">
    ...
    <webc:custom-alert-button
        text="Click Me!"
        message="Hello from my custom web component!" />
    ...

Now, to top off this exmaple, one more thing worth mentioning: In our web component implementation, we can even import and use other web components, for example UI5 web components. The UI5 web components have the same look and feel as the standard UI5 controls, but they are built on top of web component technologies, so they too are framework-agnostic (just like our own custom web component). In our example, we can replace the standard HTML button with the ui5-button web component from the UI5 web components library:

import "@ui5/webcomponents/dist/Button.js"

class CustomAlertButton extends HTMLElement {

    ...

    render() {
        const text = this.getAttribute("text") || this.text
        const message = this.getAttribute("message") || this.message
        let button
        if (!this.shadowRoot.querySelector("ui5-button")) {
            button = document.createElement("ui5-button")
            this.shadowRoot.appendChild(button)
        } else {
            button = this.shadowRoot.querySelector("ui5-button")
            button.textContent = text
            if (message) {
                button.addEventListener("click", async () => {
                    alert(message)
                })
            }
        }
    }
}

customElements.define("custom-alert-button", CustomAlertButton)

We have now come full-circle: We created a custom web component, which by design is framework-agnostic, and used a UI5 web component inside of it. We consumed the custom web component in a UI5 application, demonstrating the flexibility and openness of the UI5 framework, and we could take this same web component to any other application as well, be it UI5 or not.

Try it out yourself and let me know how it goes!

entry.title: Bridging Data Quality Gaps in SAP SuccessFactors TIH with CSVValidationApp and Vibe Coding
entry.content:
Introduction

Data quality challenges in SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) often go unnoticed until they impact user experience. When thousands of attributes are imported without proper validation, issues like HTML tags, broken formatting, and unescaped characters can disrupt Growth Portfolios and compromise analytics/employee experience. This blog introduces CSVValidationApp, a solution designed to bridge this gap using functional expertise and modern development practices like Vibe Coding‚Äîand opens the door for community collaboration on similar innovations.

Why This Matters

 SAP Talent Intelligence Hub is a strategic enabler for skills-based workforce planning. It helps organizations create dynamic career paths, leverage AI-driven skill recommendations, and empower employees through Growth Portfolios. These capabilities unlock smarter talent decisions and a more agile workforce.

To fully realize these benefits, data integrity during imports is critical. According to SAP Help Portal, importing entities like attributes, tags, and behaviors into TIH requires strict adherence to structure and format. Common issues include:

  • Incorrect headers or missing mandatory fields in CSV files
  • Improper encoding (non-UTF-8) causing character display errors
  • Unescaped quotes or HTML tags in descriptions, which can truncate or break content
  • Large file sizes impacting performance (recommended limit: 25,000 records per file)
  • Incorrect date formats for proficiencyAssignedDate when updating Growth Portfolio attributes

These challenges can lead to incomplete or inaccurate data in the Attributes Library and Growth Portfolio, affecting AI-driven recommendations and user experience. Adding a validation step before import ensures clean, consistent data‚Äîreducing manual troubleshooting and enabling HR teams to focus on strategic initiatives.

My Perspective and Approach

Having worked extensively across implementations, integrations, and functional solution design in SuccessFactors, I‚Äôve seen how small data issues can create big challenges downstream. This experience shaped my approach: build a tool that doesn‚Äôt just validate data but actively improves it before it enters TIH.

I chose Vibe Coding as the development approach because it accelerates delivery through real-time collaboration, instant previews, and iterative design‚Äîall within SAP Business Application Studio. This allowed me to focus on business logic and user experience rather than boilerplate coding, ensuring the solution was delivered quickly without compromising quality.

How CSVValidationApp Fits into the TIH Workflow

CSVValidationApp acts as a data quality gatekeeper in the integration process. In the following example workflow after data is exported from Integration Center, the file passes through CSVValidationApp for cleansing and validation. Once clean, the data is transformed and mapped to TIH-compatible attributes before being imported back into the system.

This workflow ensures that what enters TIH is not just valid but optimized for rendering and usability. The result? A clean, enriched skills library that supports AI-driven recommendations and future enhancements.

What Makes CSVValidationApp Powerful

CSVValidationApp performs comprehensive checks tailored for SuccessFactors Integration Center requirements. It detects encoding issues, validates structure, identifies problematic characters, and removes HTML tags and entities. Beyond validation, it offers auto-correction, generating clean content with proper quoting and escaping. A preview feature and detailed statistics give administrators confidence before import.

By automating these steps, CSVValidationApp transforms a tedious, error-prone process into a seamless experience‚Äîempowering HR teams to focus on strategic tasks rather than data cleanup.

Looking Ahead: Unlocking the Full Potential of TIH

SAP Talent Intelligence Hub is continuously evolving to help organizations stay ahead in a skills-based economy. Upcoming innovations include AI-driven skill inference, integration with external taxonomies, expanded APIs, and advanced analytics for workforce agility. These capabilities will empower HR teams to make smarter decisions and deliver personalized employee experiences.

Clean, validated data is the foundation for these advancements. By ensuring data integrity from the start, organizations can confidently leverage AI recommendations, predictive insights, and future integrations without disruption.

CSVValidationApp supports this vision by acting as a proactive data quality gatekeeper. Future enhancements will include AI-powered attribute correction suggestions, direct SAP API integration for one-click imports, and support for additional modules like Learning and Recruiting‚Äîmaking the process even more seamless and intelligent.

Getting Started

CSVValidationApp is built as an SAP Fiori application using SAP Business Application Studio. To run it locally, simply clone the repository, install dependencies, and start the app.

Here is an example screen shot from the application . The Attribute text file I validate below had many data rows with competency description such as: 
"1000009","de_DE","BUSINESS & TRANSFORMATION..","<p>Sie planen Ihre Vorhaben, definieren herausfordernde Ziele und entscheiden mutig.</p><p>Herausforderungen im „VUCA“-Umfeld (Volatilität – Unsicherheit – Komplexität – Ambiguität) begegnen Sie aktiv und entwickeln eine klare Vision für Ihren Verantwortungsbereich.</p><p><a href= xyzurl target=_blank>Kriterien und Verhaltensanker</a> anzeigen.</p>","COMPETENCY"

 This description gets corrected to:

"1000009","de_DE","BUSINESS & TRANSFORMATION..","Sie planen Ihre Vorhaben, definieren herausfordernde Ziele und entscheiden mutig. Bei der Umsetzung agieren Sie l√∂sungsorientiert, bewerten Ergebnisse und Prozesse und nehmen notwendige Anpassungen vor. Herausforderungen im ‚ÄûVUCA\"-Umfeld (Volatilit√§t - Unsicherheit - Komplexit√§t - Ambiguit√§t) begegnen Sie aktiv und entwickeln eine klare Vision f√ºr Ihren Verantwortungsbereich. ","COMPETENCY"

Final Thoughts & Community Ask

Data quality may seem like a technical detail, but in reality, it‚Äôs a strategic enabler. By combining functional expertise with modern development practices, CSVValidationApp delivers a solution that not only solves today‚Äôs challenges but positions organizations for tomorrow‚Äôs opportunities.

I‚Äôd love to hear from the SAP Community:

  • Have you built similar tools using Vibe Coding or other rapid development approaches?
  • What other gaps do you see in data validation for SuccessFactors integrations, and how can we bridge them together?

Share your thoughts, examples, and ideas in the comments. Let‚Äôs collaborate to make data quality a strength, not a challenge.

entry.title: Bringing the SAP Fiori Development Portal and Its Use to the Next Level (6 of 6)
entry.content:
As we conclude our mini-series on the SAP Fiori development portal, where we provided you with everything needed to make the best possible choices for your project, it is now up to you to pick your set of building blocks and decide where to use what for your targeted SAP Fiori app. Let's consolidate key learnings that will help you maximize the portal's potential in your development workflow and look at the way forward.

Transform how you approach SAP Fiori app development

The SAP Fiori development portal represents more than just documentation - it's a comprehensive platform that transforms how you approach SAP Fiori app development. Whether you're a seasoned developer, a business analyst defining requirements, or a designer crafting user experiences, the portal provides real-time exploration options for building apps based on SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 to make informed decisions and build enterprise-grade applications efficiently.

Now it's time to consolidate what we've learned into actionable guidance that will help you maximize the portal's potential in your development workflow.

Tips and Tricks for Maximum Productivity

It is all about balancing standardization with customization. The portal structure and feature help you navigate the SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 options to maximize your success.

Portal Structure

The portal structure supports you in balancing standardization with customization.

  • Map business requirements to building blocks first - use the portal to identify which components can address your function needs out-of-the-box 
  • Leverage Global Patterns early in your project planning - these non-visual building blocks like draft handling and navigation patterns are often overlooked but critical for enterprise applications‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ
  • Evaluate standard floorplans against your use cases before building custom solutions - List Report and Object Page patterns handle the majority of business scenarios. Together with the extension points provided by SAP Fiori elements, they can often meet your requirements with minimal effort
  • Use Custom Pages for more creative app layouts - if the target picture of your application is too far from the standard floorplans, opt for custom page creation using building blocks and global patterns to get the benefits of the metadata-driven UIs, or leverage freestyle SAPUI5 to achieve your goal.

Portal Features

  • Use "Show Code" consistently - every page offers this feature to reveal the underlying annotations and implementation details
  • Experiment with live code editing - modify annotations in real-time to understand how changes affect the UI behavior. Switch off live mode for more complex code changes
  • Explore both display and edit modes - many building blocks behave differently in these modes, and the portal shows both scenarios
  • Follow "Documentation" links for detailed product documentation - the portal provides focused overviews while official docs offer comprehensive details

The Portal as Your Companion

The SAP Fiori development portal isn't just a reference - it's an active participant in your development process, already starting when designing the target picture. When mapping the business user needs to how this translates into application UI, you want to review the options in the SAP Fiori development portal since following standard patterns or use standard building blocks will reduce implementation and maintenance efforts drastically. By including the portal in your everyday development process, you'll find that it becomes an indispensable tool for delivering high-quality SAP Fiori applications efficiently.

As the portal continues to evolve, these fundamental approaches will serve you well. The combination of hands-on experimentation, systematic evaluation, and informed decision-making creates a development workflow that scales with your team's growth and adapts to changing business requirements.

While using it in your day-to-day work, help us understand what helps you the most, where things go in the right direction but lack the last mile, and inspire us for things we haven't even thought about yet.

Looking Forward ‚Äì SAP Fiori elements is compatible with AI tooling

The SAP Fiori development portal represents our commitment to making SAP Fiori elements development more accessible, efficient, and collaborative. That also includes using its content and the learning when providing AI-based development support by SAP Fiori tools. As we continue to enhance the portal, remember that it's designed to grow with your expertise.

We can think in the following directions right now:

  • Enhance the level of detail for developers, e.g. . This also make makes the portal useful as a grounding document for AI tools and LLMs that assist developers with creating SAP Fiori elements apps
  • Include the designer persona much more - bridging to the SAP Design System for the basics and providing guidance for the use of available features of SAP Fiori elements based on the context
  • Connect the explorer world of the portal with the implementation world of SAP Fiori tools

Whether you're building your first SAP Fiori application or extending an existing enterprise solution, the portal provides the foundation for making informed decisions that balance rapid development with enterprise-grade quality. The building blocks, patterns, and guidance we've explored throughout this series are your tools for creating applications that users love and businesses depend on.

Thank you for joining us on this journey through the SAP Fiori development portal. We're excited to see the innovative applications you'll build using these tools and techniques. And maybe you are already one of the next customers presenting how the portal helped you in crafting your SAP Fiori app in the SAP Fiori development roundtable. Your feedback and experiences will continue to shape the portal's evolution, making it an even more powerful resource for the entire SAP Fiori development community.

Complete Blog Series Overview

To get the full overview of the SAP Fiori development portal, check out the following blog posts of the mini-series:

  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6)
  • Get familiar with SAP Fiori development portal and the power of the building blocks (2 of 6)
  • Explore the potential of SAP Fiori development portal using complex building blocks (3 of 6)
  • Use SAP Fiori development portal to understand extension options for standard floorplans (4 of 6)
  • Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
  • Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)
